description:
AWS Certified Solutions Architect Associate exam is intended for individuals with experience designing distributed applications and systems on the AWS platform. Exam concepts you should understand for this exam include designing and deploying scalable systems on AWS, lift and shift of an existing on-premises application to AWS, ingress and egress of data to and from AWS
Selecting the appropriate AWS service based on data, compute, database, or security requirements, identifying appropriate use of AWS architectural best practices and estimating AWS costs and identifying cost control mechanisms.
descriptionMD:
AWS Certified Solutions Architect Associate exam is intended for individuals with experience designing distributed applications and systems on the AWS platform. Exam concepts you should understand for this exam include designing and deploying scalable systems on AWS, lift and shift of an existing on-premises application to AWS, ingress and egress of data to and from AWS
Selecting the appropriate AWS service based on data, compute, database, or security requirements, identifying appropriate use of AWS architectural best practices and estimating AWS costs and identifying cost control mechanisms.
name: AWS Certified Solutions Architect - Associate
subtitle: Designing distributed applications on AWS platform

episodes.description: AWS Certified Solutions Architect Associate exam is intended for individuals with experience designing distributed applications and systems on the AWS platform. Exam concepts you should understand for this exam include designing and deploying scalable systems on AWS, lift and shift of an existing on-premises application to AWS, ingress and egress of data to and from AWS Selecting the appropriate AWS service based on data, compute, database, or security requirements, identifying appropriate use of AWS architectural best practices and estimating AWS costs and identifying cost control mechanisms.
episodes.title: Overview
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.050 --> 00:00:03.629
[SOUND] In this video
we're gonna take a look at

2
00:00:03.629 --> 00:00:07.774
the AWS Certified Solutions
Architect: Associate

3
00:00:07.774 --> 00:00:11.275
certification content here on ITPro.TV.

4
00:00:11.275 --> 00:00:15.435
Now for those of you that are looking to
get certified in AWS or just learn about

5
00:00:15.435 --> 00:00:19.870
Amazon Web Services in general,
the ACSA is the starting point for you.

6
00:00:19.870 --> 00:00:23.130
In this certification we run
though basically an overview of

7
00:00:23.130 --> 00:00:26.650
all of the different
solutions that make up AWS.

8
00:00:26.650 --> 00:00:29.250
Amazon Web Services is actually
a really massive product,

9
00:00:29.250 --> 00:00:31.860
a collection of a number of
different utilities and services

10
00:00:31.860 --> 00:00:35.670
that when you put them all together create
an amazing solutions infrastructure.

11
00:00:35.670 --> 00:00:37.420
Now, who is this targeted towards?

12
00:00:37.420 --> 00:00:40.970
Well, really anybody who wants
to learn more about AWS and

13
00:00:40.970 --> 00:00:44.740
cloud infrastructure, this is a great
starting point to jump in and get working.

14
00:00:44.740 --> 00:00:49.130
But it's really targeted toward SysOps and
DevOps, people who are responsible for

15
00:00:49.130 --> 00:00:52.560
maintaining systems, and are looking
to deploy them in the cloud, and

16
00:00:52.560 --> 00:00:54.730
are entertaining using
AWS as that solution.

17
00:00:54.730 --> 00:00:58.560
So, if you fit that mold,
this is the certification for you.

18
00:00:58.560 --> 00:01:02.250
But why is it that it targets
that kind of audience so well?

19
00:01:02.250 --> 00:01:04.670
And the reason is, this certification's
a little bit different than some of

20
00:01:04.670 --> 00:01:05.490
the other ones that we do.

21
00:01:05.490 --> 00:01:09.190
A lot of times we focus
really on the how to side.

22
00:01:09.190 --> 00:01:10.800
How to perform a certain activity.

23
00:01:10.800 --> 00:01:13.440
How to perform some certain job, or

24
00:01:13.440 --> 00:01:15.910
action that needs to be
done to provide a service.

25
00:01:15.910 --> 00:01:20.680
But in this certification,
it's more of a higher level overview of

26
00:01:20.680 --> 00:01:22.890
here's what this product is and
what it does.

27
00:01:22.890 --> 00:01:24.990
Here's what this other product is,
and what it does.

28
00:01:24.990 --> 00:01:28.660
And it gives you kind of the run of the
whole show, and that's really important.

29
00:01:28.660 --> 00:01:32.820
Because when you design a solution,
when you architect a solution that's gonna

30
00:01:32.820 --> 00:01:36.750
be running up in AWS, you need to
understand what all your options are, and

31
00:01:36.750 --> 00:01:39.670
how to make sure that you
pick the best option.

32
00:01:39.670 --> 00:01:43.660
How do you know that your design is
running as efficiently as it could?

33
00:01:43.660 --> 00:01:46.700
Meanwhile there might be other services
available inside of the AWS suite that you

34
00:01:46.700 --> 00:01:50.510
can be leveraging to make your web server
or database or whatever your solution is,

35
00:01:50.510 --> 00:01:53.390
your web application,
could be running that much faster.

36
00:01:53.390 --> 00:01:56.306
That's where the certified
solutions architect comes in.

37
00:01:56.306 --> 00:01:58.310
Let me show you some of
the things that are on the exam.

38
00:01:59.320 --> 00:02:02.560
I've got the web page pulled up here so
we can take a look at it.

39
00:02:02.560 --> 00:02:04.823
And if you haven't been to this website,
it's actually very valuable.

40
00:02:04.823 --> 00:02:06.520
It's right on Amazon's web page.

41
00:02:06.520 --> 00:02:08.390
They've got everything dialed down for
you.

42
00:02:08.390 --> 00:02:11.600
But they've got a little link over on
the side to download the exam guide.

43
00:02:11.600 --> 00:02:15.650
And in the exam guide, they give
you a rundown of what prerequisite

44
00:02:15.650 --> 00:02:20.510
knowledge is expected for you to have,
as well as what is covered on the exam.

45
00:02:20.510 --> 00:02:22.330
And that's really what I
wanna highlight right here,

46
00:02:22.330 --> 00:02:24.500
is what to expect on the exam itself.

47
00:02:24.500 --> 00:02:28.310
And what you'll see is that the exam
is divided up into four domains.

48
00:02:28.310 --> 00:02:32.730
We've got designing a highly available,
cost-efficient, fault-tolerant,

49
00:02:32.730 --> 00:02:34.270
scalable system.

50
00:02:34.270 --> 00:02:37.450
Now that is a lot, right?

51
00:02:37.450 --> 00:02:41.510
We're not just saying hey, I wanna run
WordPress in the cloud, that's not it.

52
00:02:41.510 --> 00:02:46.230
I wanna run WordPress, but I want it
to be fast, I want it to scale large,

53
00:02:46.230 --> 00:02:48.210
I want it to be redundant and
fault-tolerant.

54
00:02:48.210 --> 00:02:49.930
I want all these other pieces.

55
00:02:49.930 --> 00:02:53.900
And so, we take a look at all the
different resources in AWS that can make

56
00:02:53.900 --> 00:02:54.840
that happen.

57
00:02:54.840 --> 00:02:58.610
And you'll notice that
that 60% of the exam,

58
00:02:58.610 --> 00:03:02.420
over half the exam is right
there in that one domain.

59
00:03:02.420 --> 00:03:07.200
That's the main part, the main focus
of this exam is not how to do it but

60
00:03:07.200 --> 00:03:08.550
why to do it, right?

61
00:03:08.550 --> 00:03:09.490
What do I choose?

62
00:03:09.490 --> 00:03:11.860
How do I create that design?

63
00:03:11.860 --> 00:03:15.675
And then in the follow up certifications
in these sys ops administrator, or

64
00:03:15.675 --> 00:03:17.810
the dev ops administrator exams.

65
00:03:17.810 --> 00:03:19.700
Those focus on the actually how to do it,
right?

66
00:03:19.700 --> 00:03:23.580
Here's how we go in and
we set up multi AZ replication.

67
00:03:23.580 --> 00:03:26.880
Here, we learn that we should
set up multi AZ replication,

68
00:03:26.880 --> 00:03:28.310
what benefit that provides us, right?

69
00:03:28.310 --> 00:03:31.477
So this is kind of the why
that leads to the how.

70
00:03:31.477 --> 00:03:35.155
The other three domains are important also
though, so we shouldn't neglect those.

71
00:03:35.155 --> 00:03:38.925
The second one is implementing deployment
right, or implementing and applying.

72
00:03:38.925 --> 00:03:41.965
So actually putting our
practices into action.

73
00:03:41.965 --> 00:03:45.020
And you'll see that's
only 10% of the exam.

74
00:03:45.020 --> 00:03:46.480
Data security is next.

75
00:03:46.480 --> 00:03:47.880
Security is very important.

76
00:03:47.880 --> 00:03:49.810
We need to make sure that our
solutions are protected, and

77
00:03:49.810 --> 00:03:54.280
that we don't have an unexpected release
of customer information to the public.

78
00:03:54.280 --> 00:03:56.020
That's not something we wanna have happen.

79
00:03:56.020 --> 00:03:57.729
And that makes up 20% of the exam.

80
00:03:57.729 --> 00:03:59.765
And then lastly, we have troubleshooting.

81
00:03:59.765 --> 00:04:02.815
Sometimes things don't go quite
the way we hoped they should go.

82
00:04:02.815 --> 00:04:05.265
And we need to be able to identify and
resolve that.

83
00:04:05.265 --> 00:04:07.575
And that makes up another 10% of the exam.

84
00:04:07.575 --> 00:04:10.425
So, you'll notice that those last
three domains really account for

85
00:04:10.425 --> 00:04:13.565
less than half of what we're
gonna be learning about.

86
00:04:13.565 --> 00:04:17.775
And it shows how big of a stress this exam
is putting on actually creating a design.

87
00:04:17.775 --> 00:04:20.930
Understanding why you would use
certain solutions versus others

88
00:04:20.930 --> 00:04:23.940
to meet the needs of a customer or
meet the needs of your company.

89
00:04:23.940 --> 00:04:26.703
So that's all kind of critical
information to be thinking about.

90
00:04:26.703 --> 00:04:29.898
If you have a chance to look at this guide
though, it does break down even further

91
00:04:29.898 --> 00:04:33.049
into the domains and talk about the
individual components you're expected to

92
00:04:33.049 --> 00:04:36.520
know, and what you really should
have kind of going into the exam.

93
00:04:36.520 --> 00:04:38.170
Now let's talk about
that exam a little bit.

94
00:04:38.170 --> 00:04:41.240
The exam itself,
they post the information right here.

95
00:04:41.240 --> 00:04:43.510
It's 80 minutes so
it's not a terribly long exam,

96
00:04:43.510 --> 00:04:45.020
just under an a hour and a half.

97
00:04:45.020 --> 00:04:47.890
And basically you can jump in and
take it, it is computer based.

98
00:04:47.890 --> 00:04:49.770
There's a few places you
can take it in person but

99
00:04:49.770 --> 00:04:52.840
most of us are gonna take it online
through the Web Assessor system.

100
00:04:52.840 --> 00:04:59.460
It’s $150 and once you sign up, you use
the, there’s a link over here that says,

101
00:04:59.460 --> 00:05:02.560
schedule an exam and
that will take you to Web Assessor.

102
00:05:02.560 --> 00:05:05.810
And from here, you can create a free
account and then you sign up for

103
00:05:05.810 --> 00:05:07.300
the exam which is a $150.

104
00:05:07.300 --> 00:05:10.980
The free account allows you to track all
of your certifications that you do through

105
00:05:10.980 --> 00:05:11.760
Web Assessor.

106
00:05:11.760 --> 00:05:14.530
So as you continue on through
Amazon’s other certifications,

107
00:05:14.530 --> 00:05:17.810
you’ll be able to track their completion,

108
00:05:17.810 --> 00:05:21.220
employer certificate, and other
information all right from one place.

109
00:05:21.220 --> 00:05:22.010
You sign up from here,

110
00:05:22.010 --> 00:05:25.210
and then you're able to take the exam
from the comfort of your own home.

111
00:05:25.210 --> 00:05:27.000
You can take it from the office,
or wherever.

112
00:05:27.000 --> 00:05:29.660
And you'll be able to get certified, and

113
00:05:29.660 --> 00:05:32.660
then jump out there and
put everything you learned into practice.

114
00:05:32.660 --> 00:05:36.700
And hopefully continue on with the other
AWS certifications that are available.

115
00:05:37.800 --> 00:05:40.190
All right well that's a pretty good
run down of what's on the exam.

116
00:05:40.190 --> 00:05:42.120
I hope it all sounded interesting to you.

117
00:05:42.120 --> 00:05:46.040
If it's what you're excited to learn about
then stay tuned because we've got episodes

118
00:05:46.040 --> 00:05:50.370
of AWS Certified Solutions
Architect Associate coming up next.

119
00:05:50.370 --> 00:05:53.030
Now if that didn't sound
quite exciting for you or

120
00:05:53.030 --> 00:05:56.470
you're worried about not knowing enough
about cloud infrastructure before diving

121
00:05:56.470 --> 00:05:59.600
in, be sure to check out a lot of the
other certifications we have on IT Pro TV.

122
00:05:59.600 --> 00:06:04.370
There's some certifications like Network+
that are really beneficial to have already

123
00:06:04.370 --> 00:06:06.640
gotten under your belt before
jumping into cloud technology.

124
00:06:06.640 --> 00:06:08.520
Cuz networking is so important.

125
00:06:08.520 --> 00:06:10.830
That's base knowledge that
you're really expected to have.

126
00:06:10.830 --> 00:06:14.460
So if you find yourself struggling
with the ACSA just jump over and

127
00:06:14.460 --> 00:06:17.250
check out Network+ for a little while,
and then come back when you're ready.

128
00:06:17.250 --> 00:06:20.054
All of that's available as part
of your ITPro.TV subscription.

129
00:06:20.054 --> 00:06:23.505
All right, I hope you guys enjoyed it and
I'll see you in the episodes.

130
00:06:23.505 --> 00:06:27.934
[SOUND]

episodes.description: In this episode, Justin and Don explore the motivation for using a cloud infrastructure over an on-premises solution. They begin by exploring what cloud computing is, dive into the how and why Amazon Web Services are used, and end with models of deployment for AWS.
episodes.title: Introduction to AWS

episodes.description: In this episode, Justin and Don take a look at the global infrastructure that is provide by Amazon and discuss the ramifications of that infrastructure such as security and compliance concerns. They wrap up with a quick overview of the services that are available with a tour through the Amazon console.
episodes.title: Introduction to AWS Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode, Justin and Don focus on the Simple Storage Solution service, also known as S3. They take a look at the difference between standard file storage and the object storage of S3 including creating buckets and objects. As the show comes to a close, Don and Justin explore the redundancy and availability policies for S3 object storage.
episodes.title: Amazon S3 Basics

episodes.description: In this episode, Justin and Don continue the exploration of the S3 service provided by Amazon. They explore the differences among the data consistency models that are guaranteed by S3. Moreover, they explore how to modify access to S3 buckets and files contained within using access control list, bucket policies, and IAM policies. The show wraps up with a quick dive into static web hosting using the S3 service.
episodes.title: Amazon S3 Basics Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode, Justin and Don start with a quick review of naming and storage classes  in S3. Don discusses the usage of the storage classes with object lifecycle management as well as provides a glimpse into methods that can be employed to ensure data security including encryption, versioning, multi-factor authentication policies, and pre-signed urls.
episodes.title: Amazon S3 Advanced Features

episodes.description: In this episode, Justin and Don finish up with the more advanced features that are available in S3 such as multi-part uploads, range gets, and cross region replication strategies while highlighting details to consider when employing these features. They continued discussing how to monitor and log activity as well as respond to that activity. Finally, Don highlights best practices, patterns of design, and performance consideration when employing S3.
episodes.title: Amazon S3 Advanced Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode, Justin and Don explore the AWS service Glacier as a backup solution of on and off premises data. They cover the difference between Glacier and other AWS storage solutions as well as the points that you must consideration when designing a system that uses Glacier for archival system.
episodes.title: Amazon Glacier

episodes.description: In this episode, Justin and Don start by exploring what EC2 is and what value this provides from AWS. They differentiate among the different type of instances that are available  from Amazon with additional consideration to the operating systems that can be configure with the EC2 instance.
episodes.title: Amazon EC2 Basics

episodes.description: In this episode, Justin and Don take a look at what is next after deploying an EC2. They configure IP addresses and use services such as SSH/RDP to explore a deployed machine. With security in mind, Don demonstrates the management of a security for accessing the instance. Lastly, they review the tools available for managing the lifecycle of the instance as well as monitoring for issues.
episodes.title: Amazon EC2 Basics Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode, Justin and Don discuss pricing of EC2 instances. Additionally, they discuss the tenancy types of EC2 such as shared or dedicated as well as the use of placement groups for deployment groups.
episodes.title: Amazon EC2 Basics Part 3

episodes.description: In this episode, Justin and Don discuss storage options, ephemeral versus Elastic Block Storage(EBS), for EC2 and the impact these options make when planning the system. They also discuss managing the types of EBS, EBS can be backed or recovered, as well as encryption options for those EBS solutions.
episodes.title: Amazon EC2 Basics Part 4

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Don take a look at Virtual Private Clouds(VPCs) in Amazon Web Services. They start with VPC basics, (what is it and where is it used), and then move into more specific topics like Subnets, Route Tables, Elastic IPs, Endpoints and Peering.
episodes.title: Virtual Private Cloud

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Don continue diving into Virtual Private Clouds, here looking more into VPC security through things like Security Groups(SG), Network Access Control Lists(ACLs), Network Address Translation(NAT), and Virtual Private Networks(VPNs).
episodes.title: Virtual Private Cloud Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Don discuss Elastic Load Balancing(ELB) and Auto Scaling. They begin by looking at ELB as a way to distribute traffic across multiple instances, going over ELB types, configuration, listeners, and more advanced configuration like connection draining, proxy protocol, sticky sessions, and health check. Finally they dive into Auto Scaling plans, limits, and groups.
episodes.title: ELB and Auto Scaling

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Don explore Amazon's Identity and Access Management(IAM) feature. They start by explaining what IAM is and how it's used. Next they discuss the different types of users and groups, demonstrating how to create and modify them. Lastly, they begin looking at authenticating into AWS with the created users.
episodes.title: Identity and Access Management

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Don continue their discussion and demonstration of IAM, specifically they pick back up with Authorization through the creation and use of Policies. They walk you through creating Policies through both manual configuration as well as using the AWS provided wizard.
episodes.title: Identity and Access Management Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Don dive into Amazon's Relational Database Service. Here they explain what Relational Databases are and a bit of how they differ from NoSQL type databases. They then compare and contrast each of the supported relational databases like PostgreSQL, MySQL, and Oracle; finishing the show with RDS licensing models.
episodes.title: Amazon Relational Database Service

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Don jump back into their discussion about Amazon Relational Database Services. They pick up by exploring the RDS storage options and backup and recovery features. Next they describe deploying RDS in a Multi-AZ environment. Finally they cover scaling, both up and out, and security options.
episodes.title: Amazon Relational Database Service Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Don explore and demonstrate Amazon Redshift. They start by defining Redshift's role and contrasting it with other relational databases. Then they discuss Redshift Cluster's components including Nodes and Keys. Finally they look at recovery using Snapshots and security like IAM.
episodes.title: Amazon Redshift

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Don take a look at DynamoDB, Amazon's high performance NoSQL database. They begin by explaining the basics of DynamoDB and NoSQL. Then they jump tackle the focus of DynamoDB. Also covered includes Scaling and Partitioning, Security, and Streams.
episodes.title: Amazon Dynamodb

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Don explore the Amazon Simple Queue Service in AWS. They begin by defining SQS, what it is and where it's used. Then they dive into the specifics like the Message Lifecycle, Visibility Timeouts, Delay Queues, Identities, Messages, and Advanced Features.
episodes.title: Amazon Simple Queue Service

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Don explore the Amazon Simple Workflow Service in AWS. They start by defining SWS, what it is and where it's used. Next, they walk you through the specifics such as Workflows, Actors, and Tasks. Finally, they look at advanced functions like Task Lists, Long Polling, and Closure.
episodes.title: Amazon Simple Workflow Service

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Don explore the Amazon Simple Notification Service in AWS. They start by defining SNS, what it is and where it's used. Then they go over the specifics like Clients, Topics, and possible scenarios where SNS may be deployed. Finally, they cover the advanced features like Fanout, ASW System Alerts, Push services.
episodes.title: Amazon Simple Notification Service

episodes.description: In this episode, Wes and Don explore the basics of the Domain Name System and it’s implementation inside of AWS’s Route 53. They talk about basic DNS components, the name resolution process and record types. They will demonstrate the Route 53 interface.
episodes.title: DNS and Route 53

episodes.description: In this episode, Wes and Don take a look at AWS’s Amazon ElasticaCache. They will look at design considerations through availability zones (AZ), uses Multi-AZ replication, Memcached,  Redis, scalability and access control through IAM.
episodes.title: Amazon ElastiCache

episodes.description: In this episode, Wes and Don explore more of the key services within AWS such as storage services. They will talk about Amazon CloudFront including the basics of the services, configuration, distributions, origins and cache control. They will also look at Amazon Storage Gateway including the basics, gateway-cached volumes, gateway-stored volumes and gateway-virtual tape library. They will explain the benefits of these services and specifications.
episodes.title: Storage Services

episodes.description: In this episode, Wes and Don dive into additional services provided through AWS, focusing in on security services. They talk about AWS Directory services, AWS Key Management Services and Cloud HSM. They will also look at AWS CloudTrail.
episodes.title: Security Services

episodes.description: In this episode, Wes and Don dive into additional services provided through AWS, focusing in on analytical services. They discuss Amazon Kinesis,  Amazon Elastic MapReduce (EMR), AWS Pipeline, AWS Snowball and AWS Import/Export.
episodes.title: Analytics Services

episodes.description: In this episode, Wes and Don dive into additional services provided through AWS, focusing in on DevOps services. They will talk about AWS OpsWorks, AWS CloudFormation, AWS Elasticstalk, AWS Trusted Advisor and AWS Config.
episodes.title: DevOps Services

episodes.description: In this episode, Wes and Don dive into security inside of AWS. They talk about physical security and look at the point responsibility of AWS as well as the responsibility of the customer. They also look at network security, discussing various topics like tenant isolation, hypervisors, data transmission security and network monitoring.
episodes.title: Security on AWS

episodes.description: In this episode Wes and Don dive into security inside of AWS. They will discuss account security, concepts like root account, password character length, password policies and multi-factor authentication. They will look at access keys, key pairs and X.509 certificates. Finally, they will explore the auditing services provided by AWS CloudTrail.
episodes.title: Account Security

episodes.description: In this episode, Wes and Don dive into security inside of AWS. They will focus in on could service-specific security, specifically taking a look at security in AWS’s compute service EC2. They will explore instance isolation, host OS and guest OS security, securing API access and EBS security.
episodes.title: Cloud Service Specific Security

episodes.description: In this episode, Wes and Don dive into security inside of AWS. They will discuss cloud service-specific security, specifically looking at the networking side of AWS security. They will talk about Elastic Load Balancing (ELB) security as well as Virtual Private Cloud Security.
episodes.title: Cloud Service Specific Security Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode, Wes and Don dive into security inside of AWS. They will discuss cloud service-specific security, looking at securing various AWS services like S3, database security, Amazon SQS, Amazon SNS and Amazon Analytic security. They will also explore IAM, Mobile Services and Amazon WorkSpaces security.
episodes.title: Cloud Service Specific Security Part 3

episodes.description: In this episode, Wes and Don explore risk and compliance in AWS. They explain a shared responsibility model and governance concepts, while looking at Amazon recommendations. They talk about the evaluation and integration of AWS controls as well as discussing the core areas of the AWS Risk and Compliance program.
episodes.title: AWS Risk and Compliance

episodes.description: In this episode, Wes and Don finalize the AWS Certified Solutions Architect: Associates certification by bringing together all the technologies with design and implementation through architecture best practices.
episodes.title: Architecture Best Practices
